JNL93$1004—10-04-00 14:38:23     JOURNAPGT         MILES




(JOURNAL)                MONDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1993                      1
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens,
Justice O’Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Jus-
tice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.
  The Chief Justice Said:
  “I have the honor to announce, on behalf of the Court that the Octo-
ber 1992 Term of the Supreme Court of the United States is now closed
and that the October 1993 Term is now convened. Today’s orders of the
Court have been duly entered and certified and filed with the Clerk.
They will not be otherwise announced.”

                  Appeal—Summary Disposition
  No. 93–208. Idaho Hispanic Caucus, Inc., et al., Appellants v. Idaho,
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Idaho. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.

                Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 92–1596. Liberty Mortgage Company, Petitioner v. Robin Dale
Frey and Cheryl Lynn Frey. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Nobelman v. American Savings
Bank, 508 U. S. ––– (1993).
   No. 92–1826. Texas, Petitioner v. Brenda Fay Parrish. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The
petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas for
further consideration in light of United States v. Dixon, 509 U. S. –––
(1993).
   No. 92–1968. Cordelia Ann Bodie, Petitioner v. City of Huntsville,
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further
consideration in light of Leatherman v. Tarrant County Narcotics In-
telligence and Coordination Unit, 507 U. S. ––– (1993).
JNL93$1004—10-04-00 14:38:23     JOURNAPGT          MILES




2                        MONDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1993

   No. 92–8022. Lawrence Saffeels, Petitioner v. United States. On pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further consideration in
light of Stinson v. United States, 508 U. S. ––– (1993).
   No. 92–8439. Hugo Rincon, Petitioner v. United States. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of
Daubert v. Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals, Inc., 509 U. S. ––– (1993).
   No. 92–8613. Johnny Evans, Petitioner v. United States. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in
light of Stinson v. United States, 508 U. S. ––– (1993).
   No. 92–8964. Jonathan Michael McGinley, Petitioner v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of the position asserted by the Solicitor General in
his brief for the United States filed August 6, 1993.
   No. 92–9129. Charles E. Mines, Petitioner v. Texas. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The mo-
tion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the peti-
tion for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas for
further consideration in light of Johnson v. Texas, 509 U. S. ––– (1993).
   No. 93–34. William F. Glover, Petitioner v. McDonnell Douglas Cor-
poration. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further
JNL93$1004—10-04-00 14:38:23      JOURNAPGT           MILES




                          MONDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1993                         3
consideration in light of Hazen Paper Company v. Biggins, 507 U. S.
––– (1993). Justice O’Connor took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this case.

                      Orders in Pending Cases

   No. –––. Richard B. Calpin, Petitioner v. United States. The motion
to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari out-of-time
is denied.
   No. –––. Robert L. Clark, Petitioner v. United States. The motion to
direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari out-of-time
is denied.
   No. –––. Vincent Germano, et ux., Petitioner v. First National Bank
of Bethany, et al. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ
of certiorari out-of-time is denied.
   No. –––. Glenna Sue Stapleton, Petitioner v. United States. The mo-
tion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari out-of-
time is denied.
   No. –––. Robert W. Bass, Petitioner v. Commissioner of Internal Rev-
enue. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of
certiorari out-of-time is denied.
   No. –––. Mohamed Omara, Petitioner v. International Service Sys-
tem, Inc., et al. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a
writ of certiorari out-of-time is denied.
   No. –––. First Interstate Bank of California, Petitioner v. Merrill
Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc. The motion to direct the Clerk to
file a petition for a writ of certiorari out-of-time is denied.
   No. –––. Charlene L. Perry, Petitioner v. Benard C. Dietz. The motion
to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari out-of-time
is denied.
  No. –––. Harold Gower, Jr., Petitioner v. Robert L. Bailey, Jr., et al.
The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari
out-of-time is denied.
   No. –––. Sandor Chabot, et ux., Petitioner v. City National Bank. The
motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari out-
of-time is denied.
  No. –––. Lyndon H. LaRouche, Jr., et al., Petitioner v. Pauline R.
Kezer, Secretary of State of Connecticut. The motion to direct the
Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari out-of-time is denied.
JNL93$1004—10-04-00 14:38:23     JOURNAPGT          MILES




4                        MONDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1993

   No. –––. L. C. Hseieh, et al., Petitioner v. David I. Thompson, et al.
The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari
out-of-time is denied.
   No. –––. Harold Riley, Petitioner v. Dow Corning Corporation. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
Petitioner is allowed until October 25, 1993, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Court for consideration with the motion to
direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari out-of-time.
Justice Stevens, dissenting: Because the Court consistently denies mo-
tions to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari out-
of-time, I would take that action without reaching the merits of the
motion to proceed in forma pauperis. Cf. Brown v. Herald Co., Inc.,
464 U. S. 928, 931 (1983) (Stevens, J., dissenting).
   No. –––. United Keetoowah Band, Petitioner v. Oklahoma Tax Com-
mission. The motion of petitioner to proceed in forma pauperis with-
out an affidavit of indigency executed by petitioner is denied.
   No. –––. Monty Allen Delk, Petitioner v. James A. Collins, Director,
Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division. The mo-
tion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of
indigency executed by petitioner is granted.
   No. –––. Lenard Johnson, Petitioner v. Illinois. The motion for leave
to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indigency exe-
cuted by petitioner is granted.
   No. –––. Frederic Jacob Jermyn, Petitioner v. Pennsylvania. The mo-
tion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of
indigency executed by petitioner is granted.
   No. –––. Baby Boy J., Petitioner v. Anna Johnson. The motion for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indigency
executed by petitioner is granted. The motion for appointment of coun-
sel is denied. The motion for reimbursement of expenses is denied.
   No. A–190. Louise Castro, et al., Applicant v. Judge J. Matias Tofoya,
et al. The application for stay addressed to Justice Souter and referred
to the Court is denied.
   No. D–1259. In the Matter of Disbarment of Chester L. Brown. Dis-
barment order entered.
   No. D–1261. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard A. DeLorenzo.
Disbarment order entered.
   No. D–1267. In the Matter of Disbarment of William H. Manger.
Disbarment order entered.

                         MONDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1993                      5
   No. D–1268. In the Matter of Sam B. Dunford. It having been re-
ported to the Court that Sam B. Dunford, of Palm Springs, California,
has died, the Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on May 24, 1993,
is hereby discharged.
   No. D–1269. In the Matter of Virgil Victor Becker. Virgil Victor
Becker, of Atascadero, California, having requested to resign as a
member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken
from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this
Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on May 24, 1993, is
hereby discharged.
   No. D–1273. In the Matter of Disbarment of George Joseph Golds-
borough, Jr. Disbarment order entered.
   No. D–1278. In the Matter of Disbarment of John Joseph Rapp. Dis-
barment order entered.
   No. D–1281. In the Matter of F. James Bear. F. James Bear, of Na-
tional City, California, having requested to resign as a member of the
Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken from the roll
of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this Court. The
Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on July 22, 1993, is hereby
discharged.
   No. D–1288. In the Matter of Dennis D. Correa. Dennis D. Correa,
of St. Petersburg, Florida, having requested to resign as a member of
the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken from the
roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this Court. The
Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on July 22, 1993, is hereby
discharged.
   No. 65, Original. State of Texas, Plaintiff v. State of New Mexico.
The motion of the River Master for fees and expenses is granted and
the River Master is awarded $6,496.59 for the period April 1–June 30,
1993, to be paid equally by the parties.
   No. 111, Original. State of Delaware, Plaintiff v. State of New York.
The motion of Delaware to strike the amended complaints in interven-
tion is denied. The amended complaints in intervention and the answers
of New York are referred to the Special Master. The counterclaims of
New York are stricken without prejudice to move for leave to file such
counterclaims in this Court. Should such leave be sought and responses
filed with this Court, the motion and responses will be referred to the
Special Master.
   No. 120, Original. State of New Jersey, Plaintiff v. State of New
York. The motion of New York for leave to file a sur-reply brief is
JNL93$1004—10-04-00 14:38:23      JOURNAPGT          MILES




6                         MONDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1993

denied. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case ex-
pressing the views of the United States.
   No. 121, Original. State of Louisiana, Plaintiff v. State of Missis-
sippi, et al. The appplication of Louisiana for stay of proceedings in the
United States District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi
presented to Justice Scalia and by him referred to the Court is denied.
   No. 92–989. Tennessee, Petitioner v. Donald Ray Middlebrooks. The
motion of respondent Donald Ray Middlebrooks to dismiss the writ for
lack of jurisdiction is denied.
  No. 92–1392. Donna E. Shalala, Secretary of Health and Human
Services, Petitioner v. Daniel J. Schoolcraft, et al.; and
  No. 92–1395. Walter Roers, Director of Minnesota Disability Deter-
mination Services, et al., Petitioners v. Daniel J. Schoolcraft, et al. The
motion of the parties to defer consideration of petitions for writs of
certiorari is granted.
  No. 92–1500. Paul Caspari, Superintendent, Missouri Eastern Cor-
rectional Center, et al., Petitioners v. Christopher Bohlen. The motion
for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that Richard H.
Sindel, Esquire, of Clayton, Missouri, is appointed to serve as counsel
for the respondent in this case.
   No. 92–1662. United States, Petitioner v. Ralph Stuart Granderson,
Jr. The motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered
that Gregory S. Smith, Esquire, of Atlanta, Georgia, is appointed to
serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.
  No. 92–1831. Northern Kentucky Welfare Rights Association and
Michelle Asbury, Petitioners v. Brereton C. Jones, Governor of Ken-
tucky. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case ex-
pressing the views of the United States.
   No. 92–1839. Colgate-Palmolive Company, Petitioner v. Franchise
Tax Board of California. The motion of Committee on State Taxation,
et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. The motion of

                       Orders in Pending Cases
  No. 93–405. Digital Equipment Corporation, Petitioner v. Desktop
Direct, Inc. The application for a stay of the effect of the order of the
United States District Court for the District of Utah, case No. 92–C–
178G, issued January 5, 1993, presented to Justice Thomas and by him
referred to the Court is granted pending the disposition by this Court
of a petition for a writ of certiorari. Should the petition for a writ of
certiorari be denied, this stay terminates automatically. In the event
the petition for a writ of certiorari is granted, this stay shall continue
pending the sending down of the judgment of this Court.

(JOURNAL)               TUESDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1993                   165
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens,
Justice O’Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Jus-
tice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                        Opinions Per Curiam

   No. 92–8788. Roy A. Day, Petitioner v. Donald P. Day;
   No. 92–8792. Roy A. Day, Petitioner v. Vincent Bekiempis, Jr.;
   No. 92–8888. Roy A. Day, Petitioner v. Walter C. Heinrich, et al.;
   No. 92–8905. Roy A. Day, Petitioner v. GAF Building Materials
Corporation;
   No. 92–8906. Roy A. Day, Petitioner v. William J. Clinton, President
of the United States, et al.;
   No. 92–9018. Roy A. Day, Petitioner v. Norman W. Black, et al.;
   No. 92–9101. Roy A. Day, Petitioner v. J. Terry Deason, et al.; and
   No. 93–5430. Roy A. Day, Petitioner v. Donald P. Day, and Roy A.
Day, Petitioner v. Donald P. Day. On motions for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis. Motions for leave to proceed in forma pauperis de-
nied. See Rule 39.8. The petitioner is allowed until November 2, 1993,
within which to pay the docketing fees required by Rule 38 and to
submit petitions in compliance with Rule 33. The Clerk is directed not
to accept any further petitions for certiorari from Day in noncriminal
matters unless he pays the docketing fee and submits petitions in com-
pliance with Rule 33. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Stevens.
   No. 92–8933. In Re George Sassower, Petitioner;
   No. 92–8934. George Sassower, Petitioner v. Mead Data Central,
Inc., et al.;
   No. 92–9228. George Sassower, Petitioner v. D. Michael Crites, et al.;
   No. 93–5045. George Sassower, Petitioner v. Kreindler & Relkin,
et al.;
   No. 93–5127. George Sassower, Petitioner v. Lee Feltman, et al.;
JNL93$1012—10-04-00 14:54:03      JOURNAPGT          MILES




166                      TUESDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1993

   No. 93–5128. George Sassower, Petitioner v. Puccini Clothes, et al.;
   No. 93–5129. George Sassower, Petitioner v. A. R. Fuels, et al.;
   No. 93–5252. George Sassower, Petitioner v. Janet Reno, Attorney
General of the United States;
   No. 93–5358. George Sassower, Petitioner v. Robert Abrams, Attor-
ney General of New York, et al.; and
   No. 93–5596. In Re George Sassower, Petitioner. On motions for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis. Motions for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis denied. See Rule 39.8. The petitioner is allowed until
November 2, 1993, within which to pay the docketing fees required by
Rule 38 and to submit petitions in compliance with Rule 33. The Clerk
is directed not to accept any further petitions for certiorari nor any
petitions for extraordinary writs from Sassower in noncriminal mat-
ters unless he pays the docketing fee and submits petitions in compli-
ance with Rule 33. Opinion per curiam. Justice Thomas and Justice
Ginsburg took no part in the consideration or decision of the motion in
93–5252, Sassower v. Reno.

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 93–5258. Patrick Breaux, Petitioner v. Donna E. Shalala, Secre-
tary of Health and Human Services. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The mo-
tion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the peti-
tion for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of Shalala v. Schaefer,
509 U. S. ––– (1993).

                         TUESDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1993                    167
    No. 92–1450. Cynthia Waters, et al., Petitioners v. Cheryl R. Church-
ill, et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in
oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted.
  No. 92–1479. McDermott, Inc., Petitioner v. AmClyde and River Don
Castings Ltd. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to partici-
pate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is
granted.
  No. 92–1625. International Union, United Mine Workers of America,
et al., Petitioners v. John L. Bagwell, et al. The motion of the Solicitor
General for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and
for divided argument is granted.
   No. 93–241. Ruth Jaffe, Petitioner v. Hardy M. Snow, Jr. and Accred-
ited Surety & Casualty Company, Inc. The Solicitor General is invited
to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United States.
   No. 93–5458. In Re Kathleen A. Kruse, Petitioner. The motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner
is allowed until November 2, 1993, within which to pay the docketing
fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with
Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the
reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U. S. 928 (1983), I
would deny the petition for a writ of mandamus without reaching the
merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis. Justice Ginsburg
would deny the petition for a writ of mandamus.
  No. 93–5722. Rosie M. Rupp, Petitioner v. Department of Health
and Human Services. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until November 2, 1993,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to
submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons ex-
pressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U. S. 928 (1983), we would
deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits
of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis. Justice Ginsburg would
deny the petition for a writ of certiorari.

den. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit denied.
   No. 93–5936. Gary M. McLeod, Petitioner v. Central Soya Company,

JNL93$1012—10-04-00 14:54:03      JOURNAPGT          MILES




186                      TUESDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1993

   No. 92–7794. John Pasch, Petitioner v. Illinois. The Court is advised
that the petitioner died in Pontiac, Illinois, on September 10, 1993. The
Court’s order granting the petition for a writ of certiorari, see 508 U. S.
––– (1993), therefore is vacated and the petition for a writ of certiorari
to the Supreme Court of Illinois is dismissed.
   No. 93–212. Highland Federal Savings and Loan Association, et al.,
Petitioners v. California, etc., et al. The motion of Savings and Commu-
nity Bankers of America, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae
is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of
California, Second Appellate District, denied.
   No. 93–255. Carrie Beverage Incorporated, Petitioner v. Gilbert/
Robinson, Inc. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit denied. Justice O’Connor took no part
in the consideration or decision of this petition.
   No. 93–274. Golden Gates Heights Investments, Petitioner v. City
and County of San Francisco. The motion of Pacific Legal Foundation
for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate Dis-
trict, denied.

                       Habeas Corpus Denied
  No. 93–5882. In Re John Winston, Petitioner. Petition for a writ of
habeas corpus denied.

                          Mandamus Denied
   No. 93–5626. In Re Roger H. Corley, Petitioner. Petition for a writ
of mandamus denied.
   No. 93–266. In Re Barbara M. Stone, individually and as Trustee for
Robert L. Stone, Inc., Defined Benefit Pension Plan, et al., Petition-
ers; and
   No. 93–5733. In Re Mack W. Campbell, Petitioner. Petitions for
writs of mandamus and/or prohibition denied.

                         Rehearings Denied
   No. 92–806. James H. Cossett, et ux., Petitioners v. Federal Judi-
ciary, et al.;
   No. 92–8212. Bert L. Hunter, Petitioner v. Missouri; and
   No. 92–8583. Darrell Jones, Petitioner v. Pillsbury Company. Peti-

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, and
Justice Ginsburg.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                      Orders in Pending Cases
   No. —. Walter Gene Blakey, Petitioner v. USS Iowa, et al. The mo-
tion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari out-of-
time is denied.
   No. —. Thomas M. Rettig, et al., Plaintiffs v. Ohio, et al. The motion
to direct the Clerk to file a motion for leave to file a bill of complaint
is denied.
   No. D–1286. In the Matter of Disbarment of Ellis Emeen Neder, Jr.
Disbarment order entered.
   No. D–1290. In the Matter of Disbarment of Karl Derwin Leathers.
Disbarment order entered.
   No. D–1315. In the Matter of Disbarment of Kent Hutcheson. It is
ordered that Kent Hutcheson, of Nauvoo, Illinois, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1316. In the Matter of Disbarment of James Wallace Baity. It
is ordered that James Wallace Baity, of Concord, California, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1317. In the Matter of Disbarment of Leonard Louis Casalino.
It is ordered that Leonard Louis Casalino, of Upper Marlboro, Mary-
land, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a
rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. 8, Original. Arizona, Plaintiff v. California, et al. The memoran-
dum opinion and order No. 14 of the Special Master is received and
ordered filed. Exceptions to the opinion and order, with supporting

briefs, may be filed by the parties within 45 days. Reply briefs, if any,

expenses is granted and the Special Master is awarded a total of
$32,539.99 for the period September 25, 1992, through September 30,
1993, to be paid one-third by each party.

(JOURNAL)              WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 27, 1993                   213
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens,
Justice O’Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Jus-
tice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.

                       Order In Pending Case
  No. 93–6497. Frank B. McFarland, Petitioner v. James A. Collins,
Director, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division.
The application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to
Justice Scalia and by him referred to the Court is granted pending the
disposition by this Court of the petition for a writ of certiorari. Should
the petition for a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates
automatically. In the event the petition for a writ of certiorari is
granted, this stay shall continue pending the sending down of the judg-
ment of this Court.
JNL93$1029—08-14-00 10:02:25      JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)                 FRIDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1993                    215
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens,
Justice O’Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Jus-
tice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.

                       Order In Pending Case
   A–373. United States Department of Defense, et al., Applicants v.
Volker Keith Meinhold. The application of the Solicitor General for a
stay, presented to Justice O’Connor and by her referred to the Court,
is granted in part. It is ordered that so much of the order of the United
States District Court for the Central District of California, CV 92–
6044 TJH (JRx), filed September 30, 1993, as grants relief to persons
other than Volker Keith Meinhold is stayed pending disposition of the
appeal by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
See Heckler v. Lopez, 463 U. S. 1328 (Rehnquist, J., in chambers), mo-
tion to vacate stay denied, 464 U. S. 879 (1983); id., at 881 (Stevens, J.,
dissenting in part). The request for a stay of the portion of the injunc-
tion prohibiting the Government from maintaining records pertaining
to Meinhold is denied. It is further ordered that the Government can
file, under seal, any such documents pending the final outcome of this
litigation.


                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   93–5923. Kevin Lee Zimmerman, Petitioner v. Texas. The motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for
a writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case
is remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas for further
consideration in light of Johnson v. Texas, 509 U. S. ––– (1993).
JNL93$1101—08-14-00 14:10:18      JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)                MONDAY, NOVEMBER 1, 1993                     217
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens,
Justice O’Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Jus-
tice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 92–1183. Stephen A. Knox, Petitioner v. United States. The mo-
tion of National Law Center for Children and Families, et al. for leave
to participate in oral argument as amici curiae and for divided argu-
ment is dismissed as moot. The motion of National Family Legal Foun-
dation for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae is
dismissed as moot. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further
consideration in light of the position asserted by the Solicitor General
in his brief for the United States filed September 17, 1993.
   No. 92–1465. Paul Caspari, Superintendent, Missouri Eastern Cor-
rectional Center, et al., Petitioners v. Terry D. McIntyre. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further consideration in
light of United States v. Dixon, 509 U. S. ––– (1993).
   No. 92–8957. Kimmy Lee Woodard, Petitioner v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eleventh Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted.
The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in
light of the position presented by the Solicitor General in his brief for
the United States filed July 29, 1993.

                      Orders in Pending Cases
  No. —. Tamika Kennedy, Petitioner v. United States. The motion of
petitioner for leave to file a petition for a writ of certiorari under seal
JNL93$1101—08-14-00 14:10:18    JOURNAPGT          MILES




218                     MONDAY, NOVEMBER 1, 1993

is denied. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to file a re-
sponse under seal is dismissed as moot.
   No. D–1291. In the Matter of Donald Epperson Kilpatrick. The Rule
to Show Cause is discharged and the order suspending respondent from
practice of law in this Court dated August 26, 1993, is hereby vacated.
   No. D–1293. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard A. Damiani.
Disbarment order entered.
   No. D–1295. In the Matter of John Collins Kanaley. John Collins
Kanaley, of Syracuse, New York, having requested to resign as a mem-
ber of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken
from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this
Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on August 26, 1993,
is hereby discharged.
  No. D–1298. In the Matter of Disbarment of John P. Rooney, Jr.
Disbarment order entered.
  No. D–1301. In the Matter of John Milton Pohlmann. John Milton
Pohlmann, of Lafayette, California, having requested to resign as a
member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken
from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this
Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on September 24,
1993, is hereby discharged.
   No. D–1318. In the Matter of Disbarment of Roselyn Costa Annin.

pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring her to show cause why she
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

   No. 108, Original. State of Nebraska, Plaintiff v. States of Wyoming
and Colorado. The motion of the Special Master for award of compensa-
tion and reimbursement of expenses is granted and the Special Master
is awarded a total of $59,566.79 for the period October 16, 1992, through
August 31, 1993, to be paid as follows: 30% to be paid by each Nebraska
and Wyoming, 15% to be paid by Colorado, and 25% to be paid by the
United States.

   No. 92–1949. Robert L. Davis, Petitioner v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Military Appeals
granted.
   No. 93–405. Digital Equipment Corporation, Petitioner v. Desktop
Direct, Inc. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit granted.
   No. 92–1384. Barclays Bank PLC, Petitioner v. Franchise Tax Board
of California; and
   No. 92–1839. Colgate-Palmolive Company, Petitioner v. Franchise
Tax Board of California. The motion of Government of the United
Kingdom for leave to file a supplemental brief as amicus curiae in No.
92–1384 is denied. The motion of Committee on State Taxation, et al.
for leave to file supplemental brief as amici curiae in No. 92–1384 is
denied. The petitions for writs of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of
California, Third Appellate District, are granted. The cases are consoli-
dated and a total of one and one-half hours is allotted for oral
argument.
   No. 93–377. Department of Taxation and Finance of New York, et
al., Petitioners v. Milhelm Attea & Bros., Inc., etc., et al. The motion of
Empire State Petroleum Association, Inc. for leave to file a brief as
amicus curiae is granted. The motion of New York State Association
of Tobacco and Candy Distributors for leave to file a brief as amicus
curiae is granted. The motion of Seneca Nation of Indians, et al. for
leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the Court of Appeals of New York granted.
   No. 92–8346. Terry Lee Shannon, Petitioner v. United States. Mo-
tion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit are granted.
   No. 92–9093. John Joseph Romano, Petitioner v. Oklahoma. Motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma are
granted limited to the following question: “Does admission of evidence
that a capital defendant already has been sentenced to death in another
case impermissibly undermine the sentencing jury’s sense of responsi-
bility for determining the appropriateness of the defendant’s death, in
violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments?”
   No. 93–5770. Robert Edward Stansbury, Petitioner v. California.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens,

tice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                      Orders in Pending Cases
   No. —. William Merrell, Petitioner v. John D. Simpson, et al. The
motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari out-
of-time is denied.
   No. —. Henry P. Jones, Petitioner v. John H. Dalton, Secretary of the
Navy. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of
certiorari out-of-time is denied.
   No. —. Jack Trinsey, Petitioner v. Brenda K. Mitchell, Secretary of
Commonwealth of Pennsylvania. The motion to direct the Clerk to file
a petition for a writ of certiorari out-of-time is denied.
   No. —. Thomas H. Figures, Petitioner v. Janice F. Figures. The mo-
tion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari out-of-
time is denied.
   No. A–357. Hossein Shapouri, Applicant v. Immigration and Natural-
ization Service. The application for stay addressed to Justice Souter
and referred to the Court is denied.
   No. D–1279. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard Lloyd Pipkins.
Disbarment order entered.
   No. D–1292. In the Matter of Disbarment of John M. Robinson. Dis-
barment order entered.
   No. D–1296. In the Matter of Disbarment of Kurt A. Hohenstein.
Disbarment order entered.
   No. D–1297. In the Matter of Disbarment of Arthur Allan Smith.
Disbarment order entered.
   No. D–1322. In the Matter of Disbarment of Yale H. Iverson. It is
ordered that Yale H. Iverson, of West Des Moines, Iowa, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.

providently granted is denied.

   No. 93–108. Columbia Resource Company, Petitioner v. Environmen-

Human Services. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until November 29,

and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of
this Court.
   No. 93–6130. In Re Sylvester Jones, Petitioner. The motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. See Rule 39.8.
Petitioner is allowed until November 29, 1993, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
   No. 93–6255. Lorin Steines, et ux., Petitioners v. Internal Revenue
Service. The motion of petitioners for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris is denied. Petitioners are allowed until November 29, 1993, within
which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a
petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.

                            Oral Arguments

  No. 92–1223. United States Department of Defense, et al., Petition-
ers v. Federal Labor Relations Authority, et al. Argued by Mr. Chris-
topher J. Wright for the petitioners and by Mr. David M. Smith for
the respondents.
JNL93$1108—08-14-00 14:15:04    JOURNAPGT         MILES




                       MONDAY, NOVEMBER 8, 1993                   273
   No. 92–74. Department of Revenue of Oregon, Petitioner v. ACF
Industries, Inc., et al. Argued by Ms. Virginia L. Linder for the peti-
tioner, by Mr. Kent L. Jones for the United States as amicus curiae,
by special leave of the Court, and by Mr. Carter G. Phillips for the
respondents.

tioners v. Gary Lee Roller. Argued by Mr. Carl N. Lundberg for the

the respondent.

                               Opinions

   No. 91–1523. Florence County School District Four, et al., Petition-
ers v. Shannon Carter, a minor by and through her father, and next
friend, Emory D. Carter. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion
by Justice O’Connor.
  No. 92–1168. Teresa Harris, Petitioner v. Forklift Systems, Inc. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and the case is remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O’Connor.
Concurring opinion by Justice Scalia. Concurring opinion by Justice
Ginsburg.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                     Orders in Pending Cases
   No. –––. Vincent Germano, et ux., Petitioners v. First National Bank
of Bethany, et al. The motion of petitioners for reconsideration of the
order of October 4, 1993, is denied.
   No. D–1306. In the Matter of John I. Rogers, III. John I. Rogers,
III, of Bennettsville, South Carolina, having requested to resign as a
member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken
from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this
Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on September 24,
1993, is hereby discharged.
   No. D–1325. In the Matter of Disbarment of Victor V. Savoca. It is
ordered that Victor V. Savoca, of Commack, New York, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1326. In the Matter of Disbarment of Mark Alan Lobar. It is
ordered that Mark Alan Lobar, of Washington, D. C., be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1327. In the Matter of Disbarment of Mark Gregory Wolfe. It
is ordered that Mark Gregory Wolfe, of Reston, Virginia, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1328. In the Matter of Disbarment of Thomas Henry Carver.

be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why
he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

of this Court.

  Adjourned until this afternoon at 3:00 o’clock.



   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens,
Justice O’Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Jus-
tice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.


  The Chief Justice said:
   “The Court is in special session this afternoon to receive the Resolu-
tions of the Bar of the Supreme Court in tribute to our former col-
league and friend, the late Justice Thurgood Marshall.
  “The Court recognizes the Solicitor General.”
  Mr. Solicitor General Days addressed the Court as follows:
  “Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: At a meeting this
afternoon, the members of the Bar of this Court unamiously adopted
JNL93$1115—10-04-00 15:28:11     JOURNAPGT          MILES




                        MONDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 1993                   297
a Resolution memorializing our regard for the late Justice Thurgood
Marshall and expressing our profound sorrow at his death. With the
Court’s leave, I am honored to present this resolution to the Court.

                            “Resolution”
   “The members of the Bar of the Supreme Court of the United States
met today to record our respect, admiration, and great affection for
Thurgood Marshall, who served this Court as Associate Justice from
1967 to the time of his retirement in 1991. A lawyer and jurist of world-
wide renown, Justice Marshall’s legal career of almost 60 years embod-
ied an unyielding commitment to equal justice under law.
   “While many great figures participated in the American struggle for
civil rights and civil liberties, none was more important than Thurgood
Marshall. His dedication to the living Constitution and legal institu-
tions of America kept him focused on the importance of individual
rights and liberties, not only for African-Americans, but also for
women, the poor, and other under-represented people. During his life-
time Thurgood Marshall dominated the legal landscape, tenaciously
pushing race relations along the path of equality in courtrooms, class-
rooms, and corporate boardrooms.
   “A chronicle of the extraordinary life and contributions of this legal
legend reveals the many facets of his character. As civil rights advo-
cate, as Associate Justice of this Court, as mentor, as leader, as ambas-
sador of good will, and as friend, he was a man of incredible vision and
unquestioned commitment. We owe an enormous debt of gratitude to
his devoted wife Cissy and his wonderful sons, Goody and John for
sharing him with us and with the nation. His inherent sense of fairness
and his faith in the basic decency of the American people, inspired his
advocacy, his writing, and his courage to imagine a better world and
to make the imagined world real.
   “Born on July 2, 1908, in Baltimore, Maryland, to William and
Norma Williams Marshall, young Thurgood attended the local elemen-
tary and secondary schools for “colored” children. His childhood memo-
ries of this segregated city—the unfair treatment and discrimination
he experienced first hand—etched indelible impressions in his mind.
His father worked as a Pullman car waiter and later as head steward
at the Gibson Country Club. His mother taught elementary school and
made great sacrifices to send young Thurgood to college at Lincoln
University in Chester County, Pennsylvania. She pawned her wedding
and engagement rings to help pay his college expenses. Marshall also
worked at numerous summer jobs to defray his expenses. Accepted
JNL93$1115—10-04-00 15:28:11      JOURNAPGT          MILES




298                     MONDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 1993

one summer for the position as a helper on the Pullman trains, he
inquired about obtaining a larger pair of trousers for his uniform to
accommodate his long legs. The white conductor glared at him saying,
‘Look boy, don’t you know that it is easier for me to get a new Negro
than a new pair of pants!’
   “Graduating with honors from Lincoln in 1929, Marshall knew that
rejection by the all white University of Maryland Law School was cer-
tain. He then made the fortunate decision to enroll at the Howard Uni-
versity School of Law in the District of Columbia. There he began
his apprenticeship and with Dean Charles Hamilton Houston, a great
constitutional scholar and creative genius who helped to develop the
civil rights strategies. Thurgood and his Howard colleagues refined,
defined, and implemented these strategies in the classrooms and even-
tually in the courts, leading to great victories in the 40’s, 50’s, and
the 60’s.
   “Marshall graduated first in his class from Howard in 1933 and began
private practice in Baltimore. But most of his time was spent in volun-
tary support of the local NAACP. One of his first cases was against the
University of Maryland Law School to force it to admit black students.
He succeeded and was responsible for the first black law student’s en-
rollment in 1935.
   “In 1936 Houston called Marshall to join him at the New York head-
quarters of the NAACP national legal staff. He was appointed chief
legal officer in 1938, following in the steps of Houston. In 1940, Marshall
helped to establish ‘the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund,
Inc.’ (popularly called the Inc. Fund or LDF) as a litigation and public
education entity separate from the NAACP. He served with great dis-
tinction as its Director/Counsel until his appointment to the Federal
Bench.
   “As the principal architect and exponent of the Inc. Fund’s civil
rights strategy, Marshall travelled constantly. He spent long hours,
even days devoted to the civil rights struggle analyzing and arguing
landmark cases. Even as he prepared for the ultimate civil rights battle
in the 1954 school cases, Buster, his first wife, was struggling with her
own fight against cancer. She never revealed how sick she was until
after the Brown decision. Her personal struggle inspired Marshall to
continue his fight for equal justice.
   “Thurgood Marshall waged extraordinary legal battles. For more
than 30 years he fought discrimination wherever it arose—in educa-
tion, in employment, in voting rights, and in the criminal law. As the
lead LDF trial attorney, he worked closely with Charles Houston,
JNL93$1115—10-04-00 15:28:11       JOURNAPGT           MILES




                         MONDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 1993                       299
William Hastie, William Coleman, Jack Greenberg Lou Pollak, and
other brilliant African-American and white lawyers who joined the
civil rights vanguard. Together this distinguished team labored to im-
plement a bold master plan for civil rights and litigate the cases that
established the legal foundation for Brown and its progeny. Of Mar-
shall’s thirty-two civil rights cases before the Supreme Court, He won
twenty-nine—an extraordinary record.
   “Clearly, each victory broke new ground. However, none was more
important in American jurisprudence and in the lives of millions of
people than the watershed decisions in Brown v. Board of Education
in Topeka, Kansas 347 U. S. 483 (1954); 349 U. S. 294 (1955). In these
unanimous decisions, the Supreme Court began the process of disman-
tling racial segregation in the Nation’s public schools.
   “The Court ruled that all children had the right to attend schools
that were not segregated by race. The decision struck down racial dis-
crimination in education and abandoned forever the doctrine of ‘sepa-
rate but equal’. With the help of Dr. Kenneth Clark, a noted black
psychologist, Marshall demonstrated the harm to children who were
forced into all black classrooms. Marshall argued persuasively and pas-
sionately for an end to this intolerable practice and to the insidious
justification based on the inherent inferiority of the black man.
   “Brown stands for the proposition that law can change the world and
that the Supreme Court, as the interpreter of the law, can play a force-
ful role in fulfilling the highest human values. The importance of the
Brown decision cannot be overstated. It repudiated the previous justi-
fications for legally sanctioned discrimination in the public classrooms
of America. Although elimination and erosion of the vestiges of dis-
crimination moved very slowly, Marshall never gave up hope. He never
despaired. He never stopped fighting for the elimination of inequality
and injustice wherever it appeared.
   “As important as Brown and its progeny were, they should not
eclipse Marshall’s accomplishment in fighting segregation at the ballot
box. As Marshall himself said: ‘I don’t know whether the voting case
or the desegregation case was more important. Without the ballot,
you have no citizenship, no status, no power in this country. But,
without the chance to get an education, you have no capacity to use
the ballot effectively.’1 In winning the ‘white only’ primary litigation,
Smith v. Allwright,2 Marshall teamed with Bill Hastie, his friend and
 1
   Carl T. Rowan “Dreammakers and Dreambreakers: The World of Justice Thurgood
Marshall”, Little Brown & Company (1993), p. 129
 2
   321 U. S. 649 (1944).
JNL93$1115—10-04-00 15:28:11           JOURNAPGT              MILES




300                         MONDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 1993

former Howard Professor, to win for African Americans a more sig-
nificant voice at the ballot box. While the impact of this decision was
not the immediate enlargement of the voting power of blacks, ‘it lent
legitimacy to the arguments of lawyers [such as Marshall] who contin-
ued to complain to the United States Attorney General about discrimi-
natory voting barriers in the South.’3 Ultimately, Marshall’s efforts
and those of his cooperating attorneys would forever change the face
of city halls, state legislatures, governors’ mansions, political parties,
and political nominating conventions. Eventually America came to ac-
cept black candidates for political office at the local, state and Federal
levels.
   “Marshall’s work outside of the United States reflected the breadth
of his concern for equity and fairness for people of color throughout
the world. During the fifties and sixties the emerging independent na-
tions of Africa turned to American constitutional scholars for assist-
ance in shaping the legal framework that would govern the new rights
and responsibilities of their citizens.
   “In 1961 Jomo Kenyatta, the great leader of Kenya, asked Thurgood
Marshall for help. Marshall traveled to London and Kenya, working
tirelessly for weeks with the Constitutional Conference of Kenya. He
relied on the model of fundamental rights in the American Declaration
of Independence and the Constitution. Marshall put into words a world
in which Kenyatta’s dream of an independent nation with a black ma-
jority population under the rule of law became a reality. Mindful of the
hardships and inequities of black Americans struggling to end segrega-
tion and to become full participants in the democratic process, Marshall
focused on the integrity of the electoral process, the legislative forum,
and the role of the courts in interpreting the basic tenets of the law
and in protecting the rights of the minority—in the case of Kenya a
white minority.
   “In 1951 Marshall traveled to Japan and Korea to investigate the
disproportionately high incidence of courts martials and disciplinary
actions against ‘colored’ soldiers. He found blatant disparities in
charges and punishment imposed on black soldiers when compared to
white soldiers in similar circumstances, especially in the Army. He
challenged the unfairness of treatment and the absence of any modi-
cum of due process in the ‘frontier justice’ of the military courts. With
his customary candor and persuasive arguments, Marshall was able to
document these practices, to bring this situation into public view, and
  3
    J. Clay Smith, Jr., “Emancipation: The Making of the Black Lawyer, 1844-1944”, Uni-
versity of Pennsylvania Press p. 18 (1993).
JNL93$1115—10-04-00 15:28:11           JOURNAPGT             MILES




                            MONDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 1993                            301
to enlist congressional pressure to curtail these discriminatory prac-
tices against black soldiers.
   “In 1961, President John F. Kennedy nominated Thurgood Marshall
for appointment to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit. He was given a recess appointment in October, 1961 and con-
firmed by the Senate in 1962. Unfortunately, his confirmation was
stalled for a year by a group of segregationist Senators. Despite these
tactics, Marshall served with distinction as an appellate jurist for sev-
eral years. In 1965, President Lyndon Baines Johnson named him Solic-
itor General of the United States, the first African American to hold
that position. As the nation’s top appellate lawyer, Thurgood Marshall
successfully defended before the Supreme Court the constitutionality
of numerous statutes, including the 1965 Voting Rights Act which se-
cured equal voting privileges for all Americans.
   “In 1967 President Johnson called Marshall to the White House and
advised him of his intention to nominate Marshall to become an Associ-
ate Justice of the Supreme Court. As the first African-American in the
history of the United States so honored, Marshall’s becoming part of
the Court showed how much he had changed the world. Typically, Mar-
shall asked LBJ for a moment to share his news with his devoted wife
Cissy before the press was advised. Characteristically, he also said to
LBJ in a more serious tone, that he would ‘call them as he saw them’.
LBJ responded that he would expect nothing less. Although a bitter
Senate confirmation fight erupted again, Marshall was confirmed and
sworn in on August 20, 1967.
   “During his twenty-four year tenure on the Court, Justice Marshall
served as the conscience of the Court. With firm and unwavering
conviction, he aggressively challenged his colleagues and counsel on
issues of racism, bigotry, sexism, sexual preference, and prejudice
with his sharp mind, candid speech and powerful pen. His questions at
oral argument would unerringly uncover the fundamental issues of
fairness that lay at the core of the cases facing the Court. Often in
concert with his great friend and ally, William Brennan, Marshall ar-
gued against artificial barriers to human dignity and individual rights.
On many occasions Marshall dissented vigorously from what he be-
lieved to be the Court’s disregard for the rights of the elderly,4 of
   4
     Public Employees Retirement System v. Betts, 492 U. S. 158, 182 (1989) (Marshall,
J., Dissenting).
JNL93$1115—10-04-00 15:28:11           JOURNAPGT              MILES




302                         MONDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 1993

women, of unpopular political causes,6 minors,7 and native
         5

Americans.8
   “Justice Marshall’s deep concern for protection of the Bill of Rights
led him to denounce efforts to stifle free speech,9 to defend his unwa-
vering belief that the imposition of the death penalty was unconstitu-
tional,10 and to voice repeatedly his outrage about violations of the
due process rights of criminal defendants.11 In powerful words Justice
Marshall’s opinions expressed the agony and the pain suffered those
facing charges. His concerns about their rights were particularly poi-
gnant because of his personal experiences as a young lawyer defending
black citizens who had been unjustly accused and punished by the crim-
inal justice system. Historians will certainly chronicle his impact on
American jurisprudence.
   “Even with his extraordinary commitment of time and energy to the
critical legal issues of the twentieth century, Thurgood Marshall still
found time to enjoy great personal contentment with his beloved wife,
Cissy. Cissy brought him love, compassion, and understanding. They
enjoyed the proud moments of parenthood with their sons, Thurgood,
Jr. (‘Goody’) and John. Justice Marshall took great pleasure in the fact
that both his sons chose careers in the law—Goody as an attorney and
counselor to Senator and now Vice President of the United States, Al-
bert Gore, Jr., and John as a Virginia State Trooper and instructor for
a statewide special services division. Marshall’s grandchildren brought
him great joy in his later years. He often regaled clerks with the latest
stories of young Will and the determination of little Cissy!
   “Justice Marshall served as a beacon of hope for generations of men
and women, young and old, African-American, Asian, Hispanic and
white who simply sought equal opportunities to live, to learn, to work,
and to share in the rights and liberties enjoyed by the majority of our
great nation. As we pay tribute to this extraordinary man of the law
today, we must never forget his extensive contribution to American
society. Thurgood Marshall made our country a better place for all
citizens—as leader, fighter, and defender of the underrepresented.
  5
    Personnel Adm’r v. Feeney, 442 U. S. 256, 281 (1979) (Marshall, J., Dissenting).
  6
    See Munro v. Socialist Workers Party, 479 U. S. 189, 200 (1986)(Marshall, J.,
Dissenting).
  7
    See Schall v. Martin, 467 U. S. 253, 281 (1984) (Marshall, J., (Dissenting).
  8
    Rosebud Sioux Tribe v. Kneip, 430 U. S. 584, 615 (1977) (Marshall, J., Dissenting).
  9

Union Local 590 v. Logan Valley Plaza, Inc., 391 U. S. 308 (1968).

     See Furman v. Georgia, 408 U. S. 238, 314 (1972) (Marshall, J., Concurring).
