(JOURNAL)                MONDAY, MARCH 14, 1994                   617
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens,
Justice O’Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Jus-
tice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.

                      Order in Pending Case
  No. A–758. Terry Collins, Warden, Applicant v. John W. Bryd, Jr.
The application to vacate the stay of execution of sentence of death
presented to Justice Stevens and by him referred to the Court is de-
nied. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia.
JNL93$0321—10-04-00 17:38:03     JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)                 MONDAY, MARCH 21, 1994                     619
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens,
Justice O’Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Jus-
tice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.
   The Chief Justice Said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 93–6741. Gloria Reed, Petitioner v. United States. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of the
position presently asserted by the Solicitor General in his brief for the
United States filed January 14, 1994.

                      Orders in Pending Cases
  No. –––. Thavirak Sam, Petitioner v. Pennsylvania. The motion for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indigency
executed by petitioner is granted.
  No. D–711. In the Matter of Disbarment of Harvey William Harper.
Disbarment order entered.
  No. D–1372. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael I. Smith. It is
ordered that Michael I. Smith, of Washington, D. C., be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
  No. D–1373. In the Matter of Disbarment of Paul Swerdlow. It is
ordered that Paul Swerdlow, of Media, Pennsylvania, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
  No. 108, Original. Nebraska, Plaintiff v. Wyoming, et al. The joint
motion to refer the motions for leave to file amended pleadings to the
Special Master is granted. The motion of Nebraska for leave to file an
amended petition is referred to the Special Master for his recommen-
JNL93$0321—10-04-00 17:38:03     JOURNAPGT          MILES




620                       MONDAY, MARCH 21, 1994

dation. The motion of Wyoming for leave to file amended counterclaims
and cross-claims is referred to the Special Master for his recommenda-
tion. The Special Master is requested to file his report and recommen-
dation on the motions to amend within 120 days.
   No. 92–2058. Hawaiian Airlines, Inc., Petitioner v. Grant T. Norris;
and Paul J. Finazzo, et al., Petitioners v. Grant T. Norris. The motion
of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral argument as
amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted.
   No. 92–8556. Kenneth O. Nichols, Petitioner v. United States. The
motion of petitioner for compensation in excess of the statutory limita-
tion is denied.
   No. 93–609. Morgan Stanley & Co., Incorporated, et al., Petitioners
v. Pacific Mutual Life Insurance Company, et al. The motion of respond-
ents for divided argument is granted. Justice O’Connor took no part in
the consideration or decision of this motion.
   No. 93–744. Director, Office of Workers’ Compensation Programs,
Department of Labor, Petitioner v. Greenwich Collieries, et al.; and
Director, Office of Workers’ Compensation Programs, Department of
Labor, Petitioner v. Maher Terminals, Inc., et al. The motion of re-
spondent Maher Terminals, Inc. for divided argument is denied. The
motion of respondent Pasqualina Santoro for divided argument is
denied.
   No. 93–880. Judy Madsen, et al., Petitioners v. Women’s Health Cen-
ter, Inc., et al. The motion of American Federation of Labor and Con-
gress of Industrial Organizations for leave to file a brief as amicus
curiae is granted.
   No. 93–1151. Federal Election Commission, Petitioner v. NRA Polit-
ical Victory Fund, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief
in this case expressing the views of the United States with respect to
the following question: “Whether the Federal Election Commission has
statutory authority to represent itself in this case in this Court.” Jus-
tice Ginsburg took no part in the consideration or decision of this order.
   No. 93–1222. Priscilla M. Garcia, et al., Petitioners v. Spun Steak
Company. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case
expressing the views of the United States.
                         Certiorari Granted
  No. 93–1001. Allied-Bruce Terminix Companies, Inc., and Terminix
International Company, Petitioners v. G. Michael Dobson, et al. The
motion of Alabama Water and Sewer Institute, et al. for leave to file a
brief as amici curiae is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
Supreme Court of Alabama granted.
JNL93$0321—10-04-00 17:38:03     JOURNAPGT          MILES




                          MONDAY, MARCH 21, 1994                    621
   No. 93–1197. Albert Hess and Charles F. Walsh, Petitioners v. Port
Authority Trans-Hudson Corporation. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit granted lim-
ited to the following question: “Whether Port Authority Trans-Hudson
Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of a bistate agency created by
interstate compact, is entitled to sovereign immunity from suit in fed-
eral court under the Eleventh Amendment?”

                         Certiorari Denied

   No. 93–708. Carol J. Applewhite, Petitioner v. United States Air
Force, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit denied.
  No. 93–856. Ticor Title Insurance Company, et al., Petitioners v.
Federal Trade Commission. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit denied.
  No. 93–868. Idaho, Petitioner v. Jackie Carl Curl and Kimberly J.
McCurdy. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Idaho denied.
  No. 93–915. Charles Ladwig, Petitioner v. Kentucky. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Circuit Court of Kentucky, Kenton County,
denied.
  No. 93–939. Roy McGinnis, et al., Petitioners v. Donna E. Shalala,
Secretary of Health and Human Services. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied.
   No. 93–945. Petrochem Insulation, Inc., Petitioner v. United Associa-
tion of Journeymen & Apprentices of the Plumbing & Pipefitting In-
dustry of the United States & Canada, et al. Petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied.
  No. 93–946. William T. Wuliger, Petitioner v. United States. Petition

                               Opinions
   No. 92–1662. United States, Petitioner v. Ralph Stuart Granderson.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Ginsburg.
Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Jus-
tice Kennedy concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Chief
Justice Rehnquist with whom Justice Thomas joins.
   No. 92–8894. Clarence Victor, Petitioner v. Nebraska. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Nebraska; and
   No. 92–9049. Alfred Arthur Sandoval, Petitioner v. California. On
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of California. Judgments af-
firmed. Opinion by Justice O’Connor. Concurring opinion by Justice
Kennedy. Opinion by Justice Ginsburg concurring in part and concur-
ring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom Justice
Souter joins in all but Part II, concurring in part and dissenting in
part.

(JOURNAL)                 MONDAY, MARCH 28, 1994                    657
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens,
Justice O’Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Jus-
tice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.
   The Chief Justice Said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 92–6259. Sylvester Lewis Adams, Petitioner v. Parker Evatt,
Commissioner, South Carolina Department of Corrections, et al. On
petition for rehearing. The petition for rehearing is granted. The order
entered June 14, 1993, denying the petition for a writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit is vacated.
The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and
the petition for a writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is va-
cated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit for further consideration in light of Sullivan v.
Louisiana, 508 U. S. ––– (1993).
   No. 92–8656. Edward Vyhie Avakian, Jr., Petitioner v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of United States v. Granderson, 511 U. S. ––– (1994).
   No. 93–753. North Carolina, Petitioner v. Kenneth Michael Bryant;
and North Carolina, Petitioner v. Marvin Earl Williams, Jr. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of North Carolina. The
motion of respondent Marvin Earl Williams for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is granted. The motion of respondent Kenneth Michael
Bryant for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The petition
for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgments are vacated and the
cases are remanded to the Supreme Court of North Carolina for fur-
ther consideration in light of Victor v. Nebraska, 511 U. S. ––– (1994).
   No. 93–6913. Deborah S. Hill, Petitioner v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
JNL93$0328—10-04-00 17:48:22     JOURNAPGT          MILES




658                       MONDAY, MARCH 28, 1994

forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light
of United States v. Granderson, 511 U. S. ––– (1994).

   No. D–1374. In the Matter of Disbarment of Harold P. Heitmann. It
is ordered that Harold P. Heitmann, of St. Louis, Missouri, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1375. In the Matter of Disbarment of Warren Harding McNa-
mara, Jr. It is ordered that Warren Harding McNamara, Jr., of Newport
News, Virginia, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court
and that a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to
show cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in
this Court.
   No. D–1376. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jack Nath. It is ordered
that Jack Nath, of New Hyde Park, New York, be suspended from the
JNL93$0328—10-04-00 17:48:22     JOURNAPGT          MILES




                          MONDAY, MARCH 28, 1994                     659
practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
  No. 93–714. U. S. Bancorp Mortgage Company, Petitioner v. Bonner
Mall Partnership. This case is removed from the April 1994 argument
calendar. The memorandum of respondent suggesting that the case is
moot filed March 15, 1994, is set for briefing and oral argument in
accordance with Rules 24, 25, and 28 of the Rules of this Court. The
parties are directed to brief and argue the following question: Should
the rule announced in United States v. Munsingwear, 340 U. S. 36
(1950), extend to cases that become moot in this Court because of the
voluntary settlement of the parties?
  No. 93–1284. Hoechst Celanese Corporation, et al., Petitioners v.
Leonard Gillis, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in
this case expressing the views of the United States.
  No. 93–7745. Carl I. Johnson, Petitioner v. Theresa M. Johnson. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
Petitioner is allowed until April 18, 1994, within which to pay the dock-
eting fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance
with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.

                         Certiorari Granted

  No. 93–7901. Lloyd Schlup, Petitioner v. Paul K. Delo, Superintend-
ent, Potosi Correctional Center. The motion of petitioner for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit is
granted limited to Questions 1 and 2 presented by the petition.

                         Certiorari Denied
   No. 93–8522. Freddie Lee Webb, Jr., Petitioner v. James A. Collins,
Director, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Divi-
sion. The application for stay of execution of sentence of death pre-
sented to Justice Scalia and by him referred to the Court is denied.
The petition for a writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals
of Texas is denied. Justice Blackmun dissenting: Adhering to my view
that the death penalty cannot be imposed fairly within the constraints
of our Constitution, see my dissent in Callins v. Collins, 510 U. S. –––,
––– (1994), I would grant certiorari and vacate the death sentence in
this case.

  No. 93–8542. William Henry Hance, Petitioner v. Walter Zant, War-

sented to Justice Kennedy and by him referred to the Court is denied.
The petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia is
denied. The order heretofore entered by Justice Kennedy is vacated.

Ginsburg would grant the application for stay of execution.

  No. 93–8492. Lynn Lamberty, as next friend to Richard Lee Bea-
vers, Petitioner v. Texas. The application for stay of execution of sen-
tence of death presented to Justice Scalia and by him referred to the
Court is denied. The petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of
Criminal Appeals of Texas is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Dis-
senting statement by Justice Blackmun. Justice Stevens and Justice
Ginsburg would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari.


                        Certiorari Dismissed
   No. 93–8565. Richard Lee Beavers, by and through his next friend,
Lynn Lamberty, Petitioner v. James A. Collins, Director, Texas De-
partment of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division. The application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Scalia
and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for a writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Justice Ginsburg would deny the
petition for a writ of certiorari. Dissenting statement by Justice Black-
mun. Justice Stevens would grant the application for stay of execution.

Venable, of Richmond, Virginia, having requested to resign as a mem-
ber of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken
from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this
Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on January 10, 1994,
is hereby discharged.
   No. D–1377. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jeffrey Dale Spence. It
is ordered that Jeffrey Dale Spence, of Seattle, Washington, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1378. In the Matter of Disbarment of Julius Jennings Wade,
Jr. It is ordered that Julius Jennings Wade, Jr., of Charlotte, North
Carolina, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that
a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

rari to the Supreme Court of Oregon. Judgment reversed and cases

(JOURNAL)                 MONDAY, APRIL 18, 1994                    707
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Blackmun, Justice Ste-
vens, Justice O’Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Sou-
ter, Justice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.
   The Chief Justice Said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                     Orders in Pending Cases

   No. –––. Charles Simms, Jr., Petitioner v. Marvin Runyon, Postmas-
ter General. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a
writ of certiorari out-of-time and not in compliance with the Rules
is denied.
   No. –––. Willie Albert Smith, Petitioner v. Eddie Lucas, Commis-
sioner, Mississippi Department of Corrections. The motion for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indigency executed
by petitioner is granted.
   No. A–769. Fred Andrew Anderson, Applicant v. Humana, Inc., et al.
The application for stay addressed to Justice Blackmun and referred
to the Court is denied.
   No. D–1357. In the Matter of Disbarment of James P. Carpenter,
III. Disbarment order entered.
   No. D–1358. In the Matter of Richard Stanley Henderson. Richard
Stanley Henderson, of San Diego, California, having requested to re-
sign as a member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name
be stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the
Bar of this Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on Feb-
ruary 22, 1994, is hereby discharged.
   No. D–1361. In the Matter of Disbarment of Barry J. Krasner. Dis-
barment order entered.
   No. D–1363. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael F. Erdheim.
Disbarment order entered.
   No. D–1367. In the Matter of Disbarment of William M. Londoff.
Disbarment order entered.
   No. D–1368. In the Matter of Disbarment of Roger Scott. Disbar-
ment order entered.
JNL93$0418—08-16-00 08:20:27     JOURNAPGT          MILES




708                       MONDAY, APRIL 18, 1994

   No. D–1370. In the Matter of Disbarment of Thomas John Morris.
Disbarment order entered.
   No. D–1381. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jerald Samuel Mea-
cham. It is ordered that Jerald Samuel Meacham, of Gary, Indiana, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1382. In the Matter of Disbarment of Samuel Glenn Harrod,
III. It is ordered that Samuel Glenn Harrod, III, of Eureka, Illinois, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1383. In the Matter of Disbarment of Ronald Harvey Bud-
man. It is ordered that Ronald Harvey Budman, of San Antonio, Texas,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why
he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1384. In the Matter of Disbarment of William Eugene Wells.
It is ordered that William Eugene Wells, of Houston, Texas, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1385. In the Matter of Disbarment of William Madison Mc-
Clenny. It is ordered that William Madison McClenny, of Louisa, Vir-
ginia, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a
rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1386. In the Matter of Disbarment of Norman Heiman. It is
ordered that Norman Heiman, of Flushing, New York, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

show cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in

Special Master is awarded a total of $47,568.47 to be paid in accordance

                                 Order
  It is ordered that the call of the calendar, except for any special
assignments, be suspended for the Term upon the conclusion of the
arguments in the cases listed for hearing this week.

                             Recess Order
  The Court will take a recess from Monday, May 2, 1994, until Mon-
day, May 16, 1994.

(JOURNAL)                TUESDAY, APRIL 19, 1994                   739
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens,
Justice O’Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Jus-
tice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.

                               Opinions

   No. 92–854. Central Bank of Denver, N.A., Petitioner v. First Inter-
state Bank of Denver, N.A. and Jack K. Naber. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Tenth Circuit for further consideration in conformity with the opin-
ion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Stevens with whom Justice Blackmun, Justice Souter, and Jus-
tice Ginsburg join.
   No. 92–1239. J. E. B. v. Alabama, ex rel. T. B. On writ of certiorari
to the Court of Civil Appeals of Alabama. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Civil Appeals of Alabama for further consid-
eration not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Jus-
tice Blackmun. Concurring opinion by Justice O’Connor. Opinion by
Justice Kennedy concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by
Chief Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia with
whom Chief Justice Rehnquist and Justice Thomas join.

  No. 92–1546. United States, Petitioner v. John O. Irvine and First
Trust National Association. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit
for further consideration in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Souter. Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in part
and concurring in the judgment. Justice Blackmun took no part in the
decision of this case.
  No. 92–1479. McDermott, Inc., Petitioner v. AmClyde and River Don
Castings Ltd. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Stevens.
  No. 93–180. Boca Grande Club, Inc., Petitioner v. Florida Power &
Light Company, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit
for further consideration in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Stevens.

for stay presented to Justice Kennedy and by him referred to the Court

Justice Blackmun.

JNL93$0425—08-16-00 08:28:06     JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)                 MONDAY, APRIL 25, 1994                    745
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens,
Justice O’Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Jus-
tice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.
   The Chief Justice Said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 93–764. Midwest Marine Contractor, Incorporated, Petitioner v.
James P. Rufolo and Service Welding & Shipbuilding, Incorporated. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted.
The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further consideration in
light of McDermott, Inc. v. AmClyde, 511 U. S. ––– (1994), and Boca
Grande Club, Inc. v. Florida Power & Light Company, Inc., 511 U. S.
––– (1994).
   No. 93–7599. Dunning Wells, Petitioner v. United States. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted limited to Question 3 presented by the petition. The judgment
is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in light of
the position presently asserted by the Solicitor General in his brief for
the United States filed March 30, 1994.

                     Orders in Pending Cases
  No. –––. Jay D. Scott, Petitioner v. Ohio. The motion for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indigency executed
by petitioner is granted.
  No. D–1369. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jesse Lincoln Woodard.
Disbarment order entered.
  No. D–1388. In the Matter of Disbarment of Lee J. Klein. It is
ordered that Lee J. Klein, of Lansing, Michigan, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
JNL93$0425—08-16-00 08:28:06     JOURNAPGT          MILES




746                       MONDAY, APRIL 25, 1994

within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

(JOURNAL)                TUESDAY, APRIL 26, 1994                   765
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens,
Justice O’Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Jus-
tice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.
   The Chief Justice Said:
    “Out of respect for the memory of former President Richard M.
Nixon, the Court will not sit tomorrow. The cases originally set for
argument tomorrow will be heard instead on Thursday, April 28.”

                               Opinions
   No. 92–757. Barbara Landgraf, Petitioner v. USI Film Products, et
al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Opinion
by Justice Scalia with whom Justice Kennedy and Justice Thomas join
concurring in the judgment in this case and in No. 92–938, Rivers v.
Roadway Express, Inc., post. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun.
   No. 92–938. Maurice Rivers and Robert C. Davison, Petitioners v.
Roadway Express, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Stevens. Opinion by Justice Scalia with whom Jus-
tice Kennedy and Justice Thomas join concurring in the judgment in
this case and in No. 92–757, Landgraf v. USI Film Products, ante.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun.
   No. 93–5770. Robert Edward Stansbury, Petitioner v. California. On
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of California. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of California for fur-
ther proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion per curiam announced by the Chief Justice. Concurring opinion by
Justice Blackmun.

JNL93$0429—08-16-00 08:01:59       JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)                   FRIDAY, APRIL 29, 1994                     773
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens,
Justice O’Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Jus-
tice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.

                                  Orders

   Ordered:
   1. That the Federal Rules of Appellate Procedure be, and they
hereby are, amended by including therein amendments to Appellate
Rules 1, 3, 5, 5.1, 9, 13, 21, 25, 26.1, 27, 28, 30, 31, 33, 35, 38, 40, 41,
and 48.
   2. That the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Appellate
Procedure shall take effect on December 1, 1994, and shall govern all
proceedings in appellate cases thereafter commenced and, insofar as
just and practicable, all proceedings in appellate cases then pending.
   3. That THE CHIEF JUSTICE be, and he hereby is, authorized to
transmit to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal
Rules of Appellate Procedure in accordance with the provisions of Sec-
tion 2072 of Title 28, United States Code.
   Ordered:
   1. That the Federal Rules of Bankruptcy Procedure be, and they
hereby are, amended by including therein amendments to Bankruptcy
Rules 8002 and 8006.
   2. That the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Bank-
ruptcy Procedure shall take effect on August 1, 1994, and shall govern
all proceedings in bankruptcy cases thereafter commenced and, insofar
as just and practicable, all proceedings in bankruptcy cases then
pending.
   3. That THE CHIEF JUSTICE be, and he hereby is, authorized to
transmit to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal
Rules of Bankruptcy Procedure in accordance with the provisions of
Section 2075 of Title 28, United States Code.
   Ordered:
   1. That the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure for the United
States District Courts be, and they hereby are, amended by including
therein amendments to Criminal Rules 16, 29, 32, and 40.
JNL93$0429—08-16-00 08:01:59     JOURNAPGT         MILES




774                       FRIDAY, APRIL 29, 1994

   2. That the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Criminal
Procedure shall take effect on December 1, 1994, and shall govern all
proceedings in criminal cases thereafter commenced and, insofar as
just and practicable, all proceedings in criminal cases then pending.
   3. That THE CHIEF JUSTICE be, and he hereby is, authorized to
transmit to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal
Rules of Criminal Procedure in accordance with the provisions of Sec-
tion 2072 of Title 28, United States Code.
   Ordered:
   1. That the Federal Rules of Evidence for the United States District
Courts be, and they hereby are, amended by including therein an
amendment to Evidence Rule 412.
   2. That the foregoing amendment to the Federal Rules of Evidence
shall take effect on December 1, 1994, and shall govern in all proceed-
ings thereafter commenced and, insofar as just and practicable, all pro-
ceedings then pending.
   3. That THE CHIEF JUSTICE be, and he hereby is, authorized to
transmit to the Congress the foregoing amendment to the Federal
Rules of Evidence in accordance with the provisions of Section 2072 of
Title 28, United States Code.
JNL93$0502—08-16-00 12:23:26      JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)                   MONDAY, MAY 2, 1994                       775
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens,
Justice O’Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Justice Thomas, and Justice
Ginsburg.
   The Chief Justice Said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                        Opinion Per Curiam
  No. 93–8312. In Re Grant Anderson, Petitioner. On motion for leave
to proceed in forma pauperis. The motion of petitioner for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Blackmun joins.

                      Orders in Pending Cases
  No. –––. Lummi Indian Tribe, Petitioner v. Whatcom County, Wash-
ington. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of
certiorari out-of-time is denied.
   No. A–851. Samuel A. Lewis, et al., Petitioners v. Fletcher Casey,
Jr., et al. The application for stay of the enforcement of the injunctive
order of the United States District Court for the District of Arizona,
case Nos. 90–0054 and 91–1808, issued October 13, 1993, presented to
Justice O’Connor and by her referred to the Court is granted pending
the timely filing and disposition by this Court of a petition for a writ
of certiorari. Should the petition for a writ of certiorari be denied, this
stay terminates automatically. In the event the petition for a writ of
certiorari is granted, this stay shall continue pending the sending down
of the judgment of this Court. Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Jus-
tice Souter, and Justice Ginsburg would deny the application for a stay.
   No. D–1389. In the Matter of Disbarment of S. David Schwartz. It
is ordered that S. David Schwartz, of Santa Barbara, California, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1390. In the Matter of Disbarment of Alan E. Dubow. It is
ordered that Alan E. Dubow, of New York, New York, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
JNL93$0502—08-16-00 12:23:26     JOURNAPGT          MILES




776                        MONDAY, MAY 2, 1994

within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. 108, Original. Nebraska, Plaintiff v. Wyoming, et al. The motion
of the Special Master for compensation and reimbursement of expenses
is granted and the Special Master is awarded a total of $60,059.18 to
be paid as follows: 30% by Nebraska, 30% by Wyoming, 15% by Colo-
rado, and 25% by the United States.
   No. 93–644. Honda Motor Co., Ltd., et al., Petitioners v. Karl L.
Oberg. The motion of respondent for leave to file a supplemental brief
after argument is granted.
   No. 93–908. Charles J. Reich, Petitioner v. Marcus E. Collins, Reve-
nue Commissioner of Georgia, et al. The motion of James B. Beam
Distilling Company for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
   No. 93–1103. Dubuque Packing Company, Inc., Petitioner v. United
Food and Commercial Workers International Union AFL-CIO, Local
No. 150-A and National Labor Relations Board. The motion of peti-
tioner to dispense with printing the joint appendix is granted. Justice
Ginsburg took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
   No. 93–1197. Albert Hess and Charles F. Walsh, Petitioners v. Port
Authority Trans-Hudson Corporation. The motion of petitioners to dis-
pense with printing the joint appendix is granted.
   No. 93–1202. Allen N. Brunwasser, Petitioner v. John E. Steiner.
The motion of respondent for fees and costs is granted and respondent
is awarded a total of $500.00 to be paid by petitioner on or before
Monday, May 16, 1994.
   No. 93–1340. United States, Petitioner v. Gary Mezzanatto. The mo-
tion of respondent for leave to proceed further herein in forma pau-
peris is granted. The motion for appointment of counsel is granted and
it is ordered that Mark R. Lippman, Esquire, of La Jolla, California, is
appointed to serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.
   No. 93–1408. New York State Conference of Blue Cross & Blue
Shield Plans, et al., Petitioners v. Travelers Insurance Company, et al.;
   No. 93–1414. Mario M. Cuomo, Governor of New York, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Travelers Insurance Company, et al.; and
   No. 93–1415. Hospital Association of New York, Petitioner v. Travel-
ers Inurance Company, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a
brief in these cases expressing the views of the United States.
   No. 93–7407. Robert O’Neal, Petitioner v. Fred McAninch, Warden.
The motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that
JNL93$0502—08-16-00 12:23:26     JOURNAPGT          MILES

                                   Opinions

   No. 92–1812. United States, Petitioner v. Pedro Alvarez-Sanchez. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Thomas.
Concurring opinion by Justice Ginsburg with whom Justice Blackmun
joins. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in the judgment.
  No. 92–1639. City of Chicago, et al., Petitioners v. Environmental
Defense Fund, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Scalia. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice
O’Connor joins.

   No. 93–1634. Paul Rogeau, Petitioner v. James A. Collins, Director,

(JOURNAL)                   MONDAY, MAY 16, 1994                      801
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

 Present: Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Justice
Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.
 Justice Blackmun said:
 “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by Justice Black-
mun, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition

  No. 93–8310. Bennie Cleveland, Petitioner v. Arkansas. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arkansas. The motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition
for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the
case is remanded to the Supreme Court of Arkansas for further consid-
eration in light of J.E.B. v. Alabama ex rel. T.B., 511 U. S. ––– (1994).

                      Orders in Pending Cases

   No. –––. Paula H. Wells, Petitioner v. American Airlines, et al. The
motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari out-
of-time is denied.
   No. –––. George Dunbar Prewitt, Jr., Appellant v. Dick Molpus, Sec-
retary of State of Mississippi, et al. The motion of appellant to direct
the Clerk to file a jurisdictional statement that does not comply with
the Rules and to allow appellant to represent his minor children on
appeal is denied.
   No. 120, Original. New Jersey, Plaintiff v. New York. The motion
for leave to file a bill of complaint is granted. Defendant is allowed 60
days to file an answer.
   No. 93–1152. C. William Garratt, Petitioner v. Eddie M. Morris, et
al. The motion of respondents for taxation of costs and award of attor-
ney’s fees is denied.
   No. 93–1454. Arthur Calderon, Warden, et al., Petitioners v. Ken-
neth Clair. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is granted.
   No. 93–8394. Aldo L. DiDomenico, Petitioner v. Todd M. Berk, et al.
The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
denied. Petitioner is allowed until June 6, 1994, within which to pay
JNL93$0516—08-16-00 12:28:44      JOURNAPGT          MILES

compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.

                                 Opinions
   No. 93–284. Security Services, Inc., Petitioner v. Kmart Corporation.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Souter. Concur-
ring opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice Thomas.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Ginsburg.
   No. 92–1402. C & A Carbone, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Town of
Clarkstown, New York. On writ of certiorari to the Appellate Division,
Supreme Court of New York, Second Judicial Department. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Appellate Division, Supreme Court
of New York, Second Judicial Department, for further consideration
not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Ken-
nedy. Opinion by Justice O’Connor concurring in the judgment. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Souter with whom Chief Justice Rehnquist
and Justice Blackmun join.
   No. 93–263. Matt T. Kokkonen, Petitioner v. Guardian Life Insurance
Company of America. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Scalia.
   No. 93–445. Lenard Ray Beecham, Petitioner v. United States; and
Kirby Lee Jones, Petitioner v. United States. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgments
affirmed. Opinion by Justice O’Connor announced by Justice Blackmun.

(JOURNAL)                  MONDAY, MAY 23, 1994                      835
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

 Present: Justice Blackmun, Justice O’Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice
Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.
 Justice Blackmun said:
 “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by Justice Black-
mun, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                         Opinion Per Curiam

   No. 92–1113. Gary M. McKnight, Petitioner v. General Motors Cor-
poration. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit is granted, the
order imposing sanctions is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further
consideration in conformity with the opinion of this Court.

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition

   No. 93–883. Interstate Commerce Commission and United States,
Petitioners v. Overland Express, Inc. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia
Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the District of Columbia Circuit for further consideration in
light of Security Services, Inc. v. Kmart Corporation, 511 U. S. –––
(1994). Justice Ginsburg took no part in the consideration or decision
of this case.
   No. 93–1129. Cotter & Company, Petitioner v. Robert E. Brizendine.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted.
The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further consideration in
light of Security Services, Inc. v. Kmart Corporation, 511 U. S. –––
(1994).
                      Orders in Pending Cases

  No. D–1336. In the Matter of Disbarment of Wayne Jeffrey Price.
Disbarment order entered.

836                        MONDAY, MAY 23, 1994

   No. D–1349. In the Matter of Disbarment of Garry Michael Cooper.
Disbarment order entered.
   No. D–1359. In the Matter of Disbarment of Neil Warren Steinhorn.

   No. D–1360. In the Matter of Disbarment of Bruce Provda. Disbar-

   No. D–1364. In the Matter of Disbarment of Bruce A. Herring. Dis-

   No. D–1366. In the Matter of Disbarment of A. Karl Stevens, Jr.

barment order entered.
   No. D–1376. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jack Nath. Disbarment
order entered.
   No. D–1391. In the Matter of Disbarment of William Castro. It is
ordered that William Castro, of Miami, Florida, be suspended from the
practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1392. In the Matter of Disbarment of Carter Bledsoe. It is
ordered that Carter Bledsoe, of McLean, Virginia, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1393. In the Matter of Disbarment of Erio M. Comici. It is
ordered that Erio M. Comici, of Chesterfield, Missouri, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1394. In the Matter of Disbarment of Norman C. Farhat. It
is ordered that Norman C. Farhat, of Farmington Hills, Michigan, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1395. In the Matter of Disbarment of Lawrence D. Morin-
giello. It is ordered that Lawrence D. Moringiello, of Brooklyn, New
York, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a
rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
JNL93$0523—10-04-00 18:07:45     JOURNAPGT          MILES




                           MONDAY, MAY 23, 1994                     837
   No. D–1396. In the Matter of Disbarment of Joseph G. Cairo, Jr. It
is ordered that Joseph G. Cairo, Jr., of Corona Village, New York, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. 93–823. Nebraska Department of Revenue, Petitioner v. John
Loewenstein. The motion of Federal Reserve Bank of New York for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Council
of State Governments, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae
is granted.
   No. 93–1260. United States, Petitioner v. Alfonso Lopez, Jr. The mo-
tion of the Solicitor General to dispense with printing the joint appen-
dix is granted.
   No. 93–1318. Interstate Commerce Commission, Petitioner v. Trans-
con Lines, et al. The motion of the Solicitor General to dispense with
printing the joint appendix is granted.
   No. 93–1341. West Penn Power Company, et al., Petitioners v. Penn-
sylvania Public Utility Commission, et al. The Solicitor General is in-
vited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United
States.
   No. 93–7745. Carl I. Johnson, Petitioner v. Theresa M. Johnson. The
motion of petitioner for reconsideration of the order denying leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
   No. 93–8569. In Re Fred Whitaker, Petitioner. The motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. See Rule 39.8.
Petitioner is allowed until June 13, 1994, within which to pay the dock-
eting fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance
with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.

                        Certiorari Granted

   No. 93–1199. Marvin Stone, Petitioner v. Immigration and Natural-
ization Service. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit granted.
   No. 93–1525. Michael A. Lebron, Petitioner v. National Railroad
Passenger Corporation. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit granted.
   No. 93–1504. Celotex Corporation, Petitioner v. Bennie Edwards, et
ux. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit granted limited to the following question:
JNL93$0523—10-04-00 18:07:45      JOURNAPGT          MILES




838                         MONDAY, MAY 23, 1994

“Whether Rule 65.1 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure allows
enforcement of a supersedeas bond, posted to stay execution of judg-
ment against a defendant that filed for reorganization after the judg-
ment became final, against the non-bankrupt surety that issued the
bond, even though a bankruptcy court in another circuit has attempted
to restrain execution on supersedeas bonds posted in favor of the
debtor under section 105(a) of the Bankruptcy Code.”
   No. 93–1543. Christine McKennon, Petitioner v. Nashville Banner
Publishing Company. The motion of American Association of Retired
Persons, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Sixth Circuit granted.

                          Certiorari Denied
   No. 93–683. Security Services, Inc., fka Riss International Corpora-
tion, Petitioner v. Garvey Corporation and India Teximpor, Inc. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Third Circuit denied.
   No. 93–792. Silvey Refrigerated Carriers, Inc., Petitioner v. H.J.
Heinz Company. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit denied.
   No. 93–1133. Town of Gray and Regional Waste Systems, Inc., Peti-
tioners v. Tri-State Rubbish, Inc. and Recyclables Unlimited Services,
Inc. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Judicial Court of
Maine denied.
   No. 93–1215. Mitchell Arms, Inc., Petitioner v. United States. Peti-

May 31, 1994.

                               Opinions
   No. 92–1441. Harold E. Staples, III, Petitioner v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit for further consideration in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Thomas.
Opinion by Justice Ginsburg, with whom Justice O’Connor joins, con-
curring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with
whom Justice Blackmun joins.
   No. 93–397. Associated Industries of Missouri, et al., Petitioners v.
Janette M. Lohman, Director of Revenue of Missouri, et al. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Missouri. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Supreme Court of Missouri for further consider-
ation not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Thomas. Justice Blackmun concurs in the judgment.
   No. 92–1964. National Labor Relations Board, Petitioner v. Health
Care & Retirement Corporation of America. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Ginsburg, with whom Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, and Justice
Souter join.
   No. 92–1370. BFP, Petitioner v. Resolution Trust Corporation, as
Receiver of Imperial Federal Savings Association, et al. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Souter with whom Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, and Jus-
tice Ginsburg join.
   No. 92–903. Poster N Things, Ltd., et al., Petitioners v. United
States. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Blackmun.
Opinion by Justice Scalia, with whom Justice Kennedy and Justice
Thomas join, concurring in the judgment.
   No. 93–289. John H. Dalton, Secretary of the Navy, et al., Petitioners
v. Arlen Specter, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit
JNL93$0523—10-04-00 18:07:45     JOURNAPGT        MILES




854                       MONDAY, MAY 23, 1994

for further consideration in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Chief Justice Rehnquist announced by Justice Blackmun.
Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring in part and concurring in the
judgment. Opinion by Justice Souter, with whom Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, and Justice Ginsburg, join concurring in part and con-
curring in the judgment.
  No. 93–5209. Darren J. Custis, Petitioner v. United States. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Chief Justice Rehnquist an-
nounced by Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Justice Souter
with whom Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens join.
   No. 93–609. Morgan Stanley and Company, Incorporated, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Pacific Mutual Life Insurance Company, et al. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
Judgment affirmed by an equally divided Court. Opinion per curiam
announced by Justice Blackmun. Justice O’Connor took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.

(JOURNAL)                THURSDAY, MAY 26, 1994                    857
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens,
Justice O’Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Jus-
tice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.

                         Certiorari Denied
   No. 93–8931. Charles Rodman Campbell, Petitioner v. Tana Wood,
Superintendent, Washington State Penitentiary, et al. The application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice O’Connor
and by her referred to the Court is denied. The petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
is denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun. Justice Stevens and
Justice Ginsburg would grant the application for stay of execution of
sentence of death.


                         Certiorari Denied
   No. 93–9278. Stephen Ray Nethery, Petitioner v. Texas. The applica-
tion for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice
Scalia and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for a
writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas is denied.
Dissenting statement by Justice Blackmun.
JNL93$0531—08-16-00 12:36:54     JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)                 TUESDAY, MAY 31, 1994                     859
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens,
Justice O’Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Jus-
tice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “It is my sad duty to announce the death yesterday morning of Mrs.
Warren E. Burger, the wife for 61 years of the retired Chief Justice of
the United States.
   “On behalf of the Court and the retired Justices, I extend profound
sympathy to Chief Justice Burger and his family.
   “It will be recorded on the Court’s minutes that the recess the Court
takes today will be in memory of Vera Burger.
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 92–1799. Visiting Homemaker & Health Services, Inc., Peti-
tioner v. National Labor Relations Board. On petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. The
petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit for further consideration in light of National Labor Rela-
tions Board v. Health Care & Retirement Corporation of America,
511 U. S. ––– (1994).
   No. 93–892. NTA Graphics, Inc., Petitioner v. National Labor Rela-
tions Board. The motion of the Solicitor General to vacate and remand
is granted. The judgment is vacated as moot and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit with in-
structions to remand the case to the National Labor Relations Board
to vacate the Board’s order in Case No. 8–CA–24277 and to vacate the
certification of the Union on which that order was based. See United
States v. Munsingwear, 340 U. S. 36, 39-40 (1950); Mechling Barge
Lines v. United States, 368 U. S. 324, 329-331 (1961); Board of Gover-
nors of the Federal Reserve System v. Security Bancorp, 454 U. S.
1118 (1981).
   No. 93–1079. United States, Petitioner v. Mitchell Lee Price. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed
JNL93$0531—08-16-00 12:36:54    JOURNAPGT          MILES




860                       TUESDAY, MAY 31, 1994

in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of Custis v. United States, 511 U. S. ––– (1994).
   No. 93–6045. William Edward Starkes, Petitioner v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further consideration in
light of Staples v. United States, 511 U. S. ––– (1994).
   No. 93–7816. Ralph R. Ross, Petitioner v. United States. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further consideration in light of
Staples v. United States, 511 U. S. ––– (1994).

                     Orders in Pending Cases
   No. –––. Talakottur R. David, Petitioner v. John F. Hudacs, Commis-
sioner of Labor of New York. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a
petition for a writ of certiorari out-of-time is denied.
   No. –––. John Edmond, Petitioner v. Consumer Protection Division.
The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari
with an appendix that does not comply with the Rules is denied.
   No. A–906. California, Petitioner v. Gustavo Pimentel. The applica-

and referred to the Court is denied.

                          TUESDAY, MAY 31, 1994                    861
  No. D–1397. In the Matter of Disbarment of Edward H. Cloutier.
It is ordered that Edward H. Cloutier, of Livermore Falls, Maine, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
  No. 93–1353. United States, Petitioner v. Donald L. Simpson and
Rodolpho Molina, Jr. The motion of respondent Molina for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The motion of respondent Simp-
son for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
  No. 93–7927. Curtis Lee Kyles, Petitioner v. John P. Whitley, War-
den. The motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered
that George W. Healy, III, Esquire, of New Orleans, Louisiana, is ap-
pointed to serve as counsel for the petitioner in this case.
  No. 93–8621. Bufford McDonald, Petitioner v. New Mexico, et al.
The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
denied. See Rule 39.8. Petitioner is allowed until June 21, 1994, within
which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a
petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.

                        Certiorari Granted
  No. 93–1660. Arizona, Petitioner v. Isaac Evans. The motion of re-
spondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit
of indigency executed by respondent is granted. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arizona granted.

                                  Opinions

    No. 92–1450. Cynthia Waters, et al., Petitioners v. Cheryl R. Church-
ill, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further
consideration in conformity with the judgment of this Court. Justice
O’Connor announced the judgment of the Court and delivered an opin-
ion in which the Chief Justice, Justice Souter, and Justice Ginsburg
join. Concurring opinion by Justice Souter. Opinion by Justice Scalia,
with whom Justice Kennedy and Justice Thomas join, concurring in the
judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice
Blackmun joins.
    No. 92–1911. PUD No. 1 of Jefferson County and City of Tacoma,
Petitioners v. Washington Department of Ecology, et al. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Washington. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Justice O’Connor. Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Thomas with whom Justice Scalia joins.

(JOURNAL)                  MONDAY, JUNE 6, 1994                     881
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens,
Justice O’Connor, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, and
Justice Ginsburg.
   The Chief Justice Said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition

  No. 93–8707. Mathew E. Mason, Petitioner v. Ohio. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ashland County. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the
petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ashland County,
for further consideration in light of Stansbury v. California, 511 U. S.
––– (1994).

                     Orders in Pending Cases

   No. –––. Robert Frederick Garceau, Petitioner v. California. The mo-
tion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of
indigency executed by petitioner is granted.
   No. D–696. In the Matter of Disbarment of William J. Hust, III.
Disbarment order entered.
   No. D–1353. In the Matter of J. Patrick Conroy. Disbarment order
entered.
   No. D–1373. In the Matter of Paul Swerdlow. Paul Swerdlow, of
Media, Pennsylvania, having requested to resign as a member of the
Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken from the roll
of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this Court. The
Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on March 21, 1994, is hereby
discharged.
   No. D–1398. In the Matter of Disbarment of Leland Trickett Sloan.
It is ordered that Leland Trickett Sloan, of St. Albans, West Virginia,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why
he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
JNL93$0606—08-16-00 12:49:08     JOURNAPGT          MILES




882                        MONDAY, JUNE 6, 1994

   No. D–1399. In the Matter of Disbarment of Roger James Agajanian.
It is ordered that Roger James Agajanian, of Mission Viejo, California,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why
he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1400. In the Matter of Disbarment of Joel T. Pegg. It is or-
dered that Joel T. Pegg, of Sacramento, California, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1401. In the Matter of Disbarment of A. Thomas Hunt. It is
ordered that A. Thomas Hunt, of Culver City, California, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1402. In the Matter of Disbarment of James H. Griffin. It is
ordered that James H. Griffin, of Los Angeles, California, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1403. In the Matter of Disbarment of Paul Ian Mostman. It
is ordered that Paul Ian Mostman, of Granada Hills, California, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1404. In the Matter of Disbarment of Sunao T. A. Yamada. It
is ordered that Sunao T. A. Yamada, of New York, New York, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. 93–714. U. S. Bancorp Mortgage Company, Petitioner v. Bonner
Mall Partnership. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to par-
ticipate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument
is granted.
   No. 93–762. Jerome B. Grubart, Inc., Petitioner v. Great Lakes
Dredge & Dock Company, et al.; and
   No. 93–1094. City of Chicago, Petitioner v. Great Lakes Dredge &
Dock Company, et al. The motion of petitioner City of Chicago for
divided argument is granted to be divided as follows: petitioner Jerome
B. Grubart, Inc. -15 minutes; petitioner City of Chicago -15 minutes.
JNL93$0606—08-16-00 12:49:08     JOURNAPGT          MILES




                           MONDAY, JUNE 6, 1994                     883
  No. 93–1001. Allied-Bruce Terminix Companies, Inc., and Terminix
International Company, Petitioners v. G. Michael Dobson, et al. The
motion of American Arbitration Association for leave to file a brief as
amicus curiae is granted.
  No. 93–1904. Colorado, Petitioner v. Jeffrey Leftwich, et al. The
application to recall and stay mandate addressed to The Chief Justice
and referred to the Court is denied.

                        Certiorari Granted
   No. 93–1612. NationsBank of North Carolina, N.A., et al., Petition-
ers v. Variable Annuity Life Insurance Co., et al.; and
   No. 93–1613. Eugene A. Ludwig, Comptroller of the Currency, et
al., Petitioners v. Variable Annuity Life Insurance Company, et al. Peti-
tions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit are granted. The cases are consolidated and a total of
one hour is allotted for oral argument.
   No. 93–1121. Ed Plaut, et ux., et al., Petitioners v. Spendthrift
Farm, Inc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit granted limited to the following
question: “Whether Section 27A(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of
1934, 15 U. S. C. Section 78aa-1, to the extent that it purports to
require reinstatement of Section 10(b) actions dismissed with prejudice
pursuant to judgments that became final prior to the enactment of
Section 27A(b), contravenes the separation-of-powers doctrine or the
Fifth Amendment Due Process Clause of the United States
Constitution.”

                         Certiorari Denied

certiorari to the Supreme Court of Vermont denied.

                                  Opinions

  No. 92–7247. Dee Farmer, Petitioner v. Edward Brennan, Warden,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Seventh Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further
consideration in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Souter. Concurring opinion by Justice Blackmun. Concurring
JNL93$0606—08-16-00 12:49:08     JOURNAPGT         MILES




898                       MONDAY, JUNE 6, 1994

opinion by Justice Stevens. Opinion by Justice Thomas concurring in
the judgment.
  No. 93–405. Digital Equipment Corporation, Petitioner v. Desktop
Direct, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Souter.
   No. 93–144. Department of Revenue of Montana, Petitioner v. Kurth
Ranch, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Ste-
vens. Dissenting opinion by The Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by
Justice O’Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia with whom Jus-
tice Thomas joins.
   No. 93–376. Key Tronic Corporation, Petitioner v. United States, et
al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed in part, reversed in part, and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Stevens. Opinion by Justice Scalia with whom Jus-
tice Blackmun and Justice Thomas join dissenting in part.
   No. 93–8556. Kenneth O. Nichols, Petitioner v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by The Chief Justice. Opinion by
Justice Souter concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Blackmun with whom Justice Stevens and Justice Ginsburg join.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Ginsburg.

(JOURNAL)                 MONDAY, JUNE 13, 1994                     903
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens,
Justice O’Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Jus-
tice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.
   The Chief Justice Said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
  No. 93–428. Seabourn S. Livingstone, Petitioner v. Richard M. Dona-
hey, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Key Tronic Corporation v. United States, 511 U. S.
––– (1994).

                     Orders in Pending Cases
  No. A–991. Cyndee Grigsby, Applicant v. Robert O’Donnell, Judge,
301st District Court, Dallas County, Texas. The application for stay
addressed to Justice Ginsburg and referred to the Court is denied.
  No. D–1063. In the Matter of Disbarment of Paul A. Weiss. Disbar-
ment order entered.
  No. D–1375. In the Matter of Disbarment of Warren Harding McNa-
mara, Jr. Disbarment order entered.
  No. D–1380. In the Matter of Disbarment of Arthur Bryan Cooper.
Disbarment order entered.
  No. D–1385. In the Matter of Disbarment of William Madison Mc-
Clenny. Disbarment order entered.
  No. D–1405. In the Matter of Disbarment of Marq J. Warner. It is
ordered that Marq J. Warner, of Englewood, Colorado, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
  No. D–1406. In the Matter of Disbarment of John Daniel Brennan.
It is ordered that John Daniel Brennan, of Evanston, Illinois, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
JNL93$0613—08-16-00 12:52:07      JOURNAPGT         MILES




904                        MONDAY, JUNE 13, 1994

returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
  No. D–1407. In the Matter of Disbarment of Nick J. Anast. It is
ordered that Nick J. Anast, of Schererville, Indiana, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
  No. D–1408. In the Matter of Disbarment of Brian Hal Leslie. It is
ordered that Brian Hal Leslie, of Miami, Florida, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
  No. D–1409. In the Matter of Disbarment of Louis R. Beller. It is
ordered that Louis R. Beller, of Miami Beach, Florida, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
  No. S-3. In the Matter of Disbarment of Diana Kearny Powell. It
having been reported to the Court that Diana Kearny Powell, of Wash-
ington, D.C., has been disbarred from the practice of law by the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit and this
Court by order of November 6, 1967, having suspended the said Diana
Kearny Powell from the practice of law in this Court and directed that
a rule issue requiring her to show cause why she should not be
disbarred;
  And it appearing that the said rule was duly issued and served upon
the respondent and that the time to file a response has expired;
  It is ordered that the said Diana Kearny Powell be disbarred from
the practice of law in this Court and that her name be stricken from
the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this Court.
  No. 65, Original. Texas, Plaintiff v. New Mexico. The motion of the
River Master for approval of fees and expenses is granted and the
River Master is awarded $836.00 for the period January 1 -March 31,
1994, to be paid equally by the parties.
  No. 111, Original. Delaware, et al., Plaintiffs v. New York. Upon
consideration of the Report of the Special Master, the Exceptions of
plaintiff-intervenor States of Alabama, et al. and the Reply of Dela-
ware, it is ordered that Delaware’s complaint against New York is
dismissed, that the renewed motion of Delaware to dismiss the com-
plaint without prejudice is denied, and that the motion of New York
JNL93$0613—08-16-00 12:52:07      JOURNAPGT         MILES




                           MONDAY, JUNE 13, 1994                     905
to amend its answer in order to assert certain counterclaims is denied
without prejudice. The Court takes no action at this time on the recom-
mendation of the Special Master for determining the location of non-
corporate debtors. This cause shall now be known as State of Texas, et
al., Plaintiff-Intervenors v. State of New York.
  No. 92–1012. Simpson Paper (Vermont) Company, Petitioner v. De-
partment of Environmental Conservation, et al. In light of the dis-
missal of the petition on January 5, 1994, the order entered June 6,
1994, denying the petition for a writ of certiorari is vacated.
  No. 93–986. Margaret McIntyre, Petitioner v. Ohio Elections Com-
mission. The motion to substitute Joseph McIntyre, Executor, in place
of Margaret McIntyre, deceased, as petitioner in this case is granted.
The motion of respondent to dismiss is denied.
  No. 93–1224. Todd Shipyards Corp., et al., Petitioners v. Richard
L. Edwards and Director, Office of Workers’ Compensation Programs,
Department of Labor. The motion of respondent Richard Edwards for
assessment of costs and attorneys’ fees is denied without prejudice to
refiling in the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
  No. 93–1535. West Penn Power Company, et al., Petitioners v. Penn-
sylvania Public Utility Commission, et al. The motion of Metropolitan
Edison Company, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is
granted. The motion of Edison Electric Institute for leave to file a brief
as amicus curiae is granted.
  No. 93–1652. Arthur Calderon, Warden, et al., Petitioners v. Bernard
Lee Hamilton. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is granted. The motion of Criminal Justice Legal Foundation
for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
   No. 93–8312. In Re Grant Anderson, Petitioner. The motion of peti-
tioner for reconsideration of the order denying leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is denied.
